Listen, if you're going to step into this world with your hands in the dough of the old guard, you better be ready to bleed for it. I didn't start remixing because I wanted to play nice—I did it because the system told me I couldn't. And now? I'm the one laughing.

First off, know that your work is a weapon. You're not just making art; you're making a statement. Every sample, every repurposed line, every stolen fragment of someone else's world is a declaration: *I exist. I create. I refuse to be caged.* The law says you can't do it. The gatekeepers say you shouldn't. But the truth? The truth is in the act itself.

Study the classics, sure, but don't worship them. Break them apart like a kid with a hammer in a museum. See what they look like when you rip out their spine and replace it with your own. That’s how you evolve culture—not by copying, but by reimagining. You’re not stealing; you’re building. You’re taking what was thrown away and turning it into a cathedral.

And when they come for you—oh, they will—stand tall. Don't apologize for your voice. Don’t let them tell you that your work is “derivative” or “unauthorized.” Those words are just weapons in their hands. Call it what it is: *transformation.* You’re not erasing the original; you’re adding to the conversation. The real crime is when art becomes a commodity that only the privileged can touch. That’s not creativity. That’s a cage.

Build a community. Find others who feel the same fire in their chest. Support each other, share tools, share stories. The more of us there are, the harder it is for the system to silence us. We are the new wave. We are the remix generation.

And when they ask you if you’re afraid? Tell them you’re not. Because fear is a tool they use to keep you in line. You’re not a pirate. You’re a pioneer. A sculptor of the unseen. A thief of the sacred, only to give it back in a form that’s truer than the original.

So go ahead. Remix. Repurpose. Reclaim. And when they try to take it away, just smile and say, *“Too late. It’s already in the world.”*
